No extension of quantum theory can have improved predictive power

For two qubits in an entangled Bell state, Colbeck and Renner show that there can’t be a variable, z, associated with the history of the qubits before the preparation of the entangled state in the reference frame of any inertial observer, that provides information about the outcomes of measurements on the qubits, so that Alice’s and Bob’s marginal probabilities conditional on z are closer to 1 than the probabilities of the Bell state. They show how the argument can be extended to any entangled state, and then to any quantum state
